intro: Heraclea phrygia, commonly known as the Phrygian herb, is a perennial flowering plant native to southern Europe and western Asia. It belongs to the Apiaceae family, which includes carrots and parsley, and is characterized by its finely divided, fern-like leaves. The plant produces small, yellowish-white flowers arranged in umbels, typical of its family. Heraclea phrygia is often found in dry, rocky soils and is adapted to thrive in arid environments. It has been used in traditional medicine for its purported anti-inflammatory and analgesic properties.
